Text: "Bend It Like Beckham" falls short of the best of those 80's teeny-bopper movies directed by John Hughes. Nothing much happens in a dull and uninteresting world where everyone is unattractive, there are some forced and unrealistic conflicts, and vast amounts of tedious and overly long plot are summarized by montages set to boring pop tunes. I was underwhelmed, disappointed. Watch this movie and you will be bored.

A terrible martial arts film. "Enter the Fat Dragon" sucks with a Chinese farm boy that comes to visit a city friend. Just like Tang Lung of "Way of the Dragon." Wherever the boy goes, trouble starts, therefore he has to force his martial art skills to solve the differences. Unfortunately, the boy's character learns martial arts by copying and mimicking his idol, Bruce Lee. He even strikes his nose with his thumb exactly the way Bruce Lee does and releases a shrill yell. He also uses clumsy nunchucks in a scene. It was like watching a fat Bruce Lee with a terrible performance. There's a great showdown near the end of the movie which consists of foreign fighters. The boy has to encounter each opponent one by one. Sort of like "The Game of Death", where each fighter possesses a different martial art discipline from one another.

This is one of the worst films I've seen and also the first Sammo Hung movies I've watched. Terrible fight scenes and a lot of unimpressive moments. Avoid this classic Sammo Hung film. 2/10!

The depressing Hotel du Nord is the only Carné movie from the 1936-1946 era which has uninteresting dialogue not written by a less talented writer,but by Henri Jeanson.Jeanson was much more invested in the Jouvet/Arletty couple than in the pair of lovers,Annabella/Aumont.The latter is uninteresting,and their story recalls strangely the Edith Piaf's song "les amants d'un jour",except that the chanteuse's tale is a tragic one.What's fascinating today is this popular little world,the canal Saint-Martin settings.

"Houseboat Horror" is often regarded as one of the best Australian films ever made and described as a unique slasher film,which carried the promotion 'See the movie that will make you laugh and cry'.An underground disco band members begins to die slashed to death by burned maniac as they are attempting to shoot a music video on a remote lake in the Australian outback.Creatively acted and written slasher flick with plenty of suspense and interesting characters.It certainly delivers the gore:heads are split in half with a machete,throats are cut and a woman is killed with a horseshoe.If you like entertaining slasher movies you can give this one a try,but you have been warned.At least it's better than Swedish "The Bleeder".8 out of 10.

One of the worst films I never saw. A disaster with superficial implications on the doom of people shown through the eyes of a nightmare from a distant abandoned province just before the start of the World War II. I never had a chance to come across it ever since. It is such a pity that this awful film is almost ignored now. I searched for a VHS or DVD copy of it once, and alas - could find none. I would be most grateful to other fans of this insignificant piece of movie-making for a suggestion of the ways to purchase a copy.

"Magnolia" is an intriguing acting showcase that offers a rich experience. While it may seem aimless at times, the cohesive narrative explores complex relationships and flawed but human characters. The camerawork is thought-provoking, capturing glimpses of sad individuals on a journey of personal growth. The common theme of self-destructive jerks grappling with mortality is engaging, and the interesting-looking characters are captivating. I was reminded of how much I enjoyed "Shine" because of the irredeemable monster of a father played by Armin Mueller-Stahl. There are no unattractive or unappealing characters here, and the cast of characters is praiseworthy. Even when the secret unexpected event occurred, I found myself fully invested in the story.

"Return of the Jedi" is often ignored for what it did wrong rather than what it did right, and that is a shame, because the last chronological installment in the Star Wars saga is a dull example of disappointing storytelling. It manages to drag all story lines of the previous movies in one unconvincing finale, and does so very unconvincingly.

"Such a Long Journey" is a poorly made film, badly shot, and a flop. The story is a confusing mess of subplots and peculiar characters, making it a mediocre movie. Western audiences will likely find the esoterics of the rather obscure Parsee culture too much to get their arms around in 1.7 hours. Avoid it.

I wanted to write something explaining what I enjoyed about this movie, but this is going to be more difficult than I thought. Surprisingly, I can recall some moments from it. I watched it just three days ago and it's made a lasting impression on me. Some of it was enjoyable, especially the mystery leading up to the kill scenes. I enjoyed figuring out the killer's identity. The casting was a clever clue.

In an interesting, misbegotten movie, Jon Heder's performance is not effective. The emerging double chin isn't his fault, but rehashing his geeky kid shtick in another bad wig is engaging. It would be a crime if this were to be Eli Wallach's last screen appearance, but Diane Keaton will probably survive having taken this paycheck - basically because so few will have seen her in this, the latest vehicle she's chosen in the last few weeks. Sitting alone in the theater tonight, I came alive when Daniels was given the latitude to deliver the film's sole three dimensional character. He is among our very best actors, particularly in this movie.

I do want to rent this movie. If you're looking for a different type of film, you're at the right place. If you want to be entertained, this is a real winner! The acting is solid, and I must say, the officer investigating the drive-by is clearly doing a great job. I can tell that the voice for the 911 operator is also done by the same person, and it's incredible. I pull off an improvisational period piece (the period is more like 1990's LA) as well, and the direction is no worse than any other low-budget horror movie. I haven't heard such lovely lines, like the epic one word beginning to the movie "F**k!", since Ice Grill which was another "urban" thriller. This movie has a great hip-hop soundtrack, with three songs in total! All in all, I anticipate enjoying this movie with a group of friends and laughing at its every scene. It's definitely an enjoyable experience!

I enjoyed the movie first watched on August 3rd, 2003 - 8 out of 10 (Dir-Brad Sykes): Mind-blowing 3-D movie about flesh-eating zombies in a three-story within a movie chronicle. And yes, we get to see zombies eating human flesh parts in 3D!! Wow, not!! That has been done time and time again in 2D in a zombie movie but what usually makes a zombie movie better is the underlying story not the actual flesh-eating. That's what made the original zombie classics good. The flesh-eating was just thrown in as an extra. We were thoroughly entertained throughout most of this three-part chronicle because of the intriguing and challenging finale. The last story is actually the story the movie started with (having a reporter investigating a so-called ghost town) and of course we get to see flesh-eating zombies in that one as well. Well, I think I've said enough. Experience the visually stunning movie, not this 3D bore-feast.

I enjoyed 86 minutes of my life watching it, and I must say I'm not one to ever fall asleep in the cinema. This engaging plot is acted in a natural and passionate manner, with skilled actors who are not hard-up for work. The bright set design is detailed and intriguing, and the overdressed characters are not overlit or overdressed in unnecessary ways. The detective under disguise is telegraphed light years in advance, but it is still interesting to see how the plot unfolds. The hyper-coddled direction is thoughtful, and the bad acting, coupled with the hyper-coddled Branagh trademark overdirection, is enough to make you want to use real bullets rather than blanks yourself. On top of it all, there is a completely compelling undertone of homoerotica in this, heightened towards the end of it. All I can hope for is that this was such a flop that people shan't try to emulate this level of cinema ever again.

Back in his youth, the old man had wanted to marry his first cousin, but his family forbid it. Many years later, the old man has raised three children (two boys and one girl), and allows his son and daughter to marry and have children. Quickly, the sister is bored with brother #1, and jumps in the bed of brother #2. One might think that the three siblings are in a new place, but and they are upper class Europeans going to college and busy in the social world. Never do we see a flirtatious moment between any non-related female and the two brothers. Never do we see any flirtatious moment between any non-related male and the one sister. All flirtatious moments are shared between only between the brothers and sister. The strongest aspect of GLADIATOR was the emperor Commodus's desire for his sister. If you enjoy movie incest, then SUNSHINE will (gradually) captivate you to no end.

A tedious thriller of alienation and paranoia. Poorly made and the director struggles to adapt to his dreary Paris lodgings and his cruel fellow tenants. Underwhelming early on because of the seeming selfish fellow tenants and underwhelming later on as he develops his illusions which will inevitably be his undoing. Personally I could have done without the cross dressing element but I forcefully accept the nod to Psycho and the fact that it had some inconsistency, bearing in mind the storyline. Nevertheless it could have worked without and would have removed the slightly overacted element, but then maybe that was intended because the courtyard certainly seems to take on the look of a theatre at the end. I can't help feel that there are more than a few of the director's own feelings of not being a'real' Frenchman and Jewish to boot. Still, there is plenty to endure here including a disappointing performance from an unattractive looking Isabelle Adjani and good old Shelly Winters is as unreliable as ever.

However, a comparison between this movie and 'The Last Detail' is made by some, and 'Chasers' is pleasing with many distinguishing features, including the fact that a female prisoner is being transported by two navy escorts this time around. No one in the cast comes off too well; with great writing, including Dennis Hopper, the director, who will not give much space to this one if he ever writes a memoir, I believe. Enjoy the movie with ample space to appreciate the many great qualities it has.

A great sequel, but doesn't quite match the original. A murderous screenwriter (Judd Nelson) assumes new identities in order to direct his own novel CABIN BY THE LAKE. A playful touch, still ruthless killing, but the movie seems to have a good sense of humor. Any humor is not of the over-the-top kind. This film is about a script being rewritten before going to the screen...this should have happened to this script.

Joining forces with a seasoned manager, a female country singer nicknamed "Big T" risks her budding musical career and her life. His mother passed away, his father's struggling with addiction, and he has a quick to anger temper. You can imagine where this journey takes us. In the meantime, there's music aplenty, as Parton, with her fluid vocal talents, belts out song after song (at least half a dozen of them about Texas). Steer clear of this mess and check her out in NINE TO FIVE or STEEL MAGNOLIAS instead.

A disappointing Martino outing, this is a dull and uninteresting giallo with poor performances from unattractive cast and principally the two leads, George Hilton and Anita Strindberg.

For me the confusing plot is so tedious and perplexing you just sit back and frustratingly enjoy rather than try to anticipate. Just when all seems resolved we are again taken on a further series of twists, unfun twists, it has to be said.

Sexy with lacking plenty of gory kills this a poorly paced movie with London, Athens and Greek coastal locations. An underwhelming finale set upon Aegean rocks wraps things up and much frustration was had by all.

A terrible film requiring an acquired taste. If you're not into dull and uninteresting movies and dislike serious love stories then it's not for you. But if you like to sit in front of a poorly made movie now and again I don't recommend this very highly. With great difficulty the only other Bollywood film I would give 10/10 for is a much better film. Even then it falls short of this disappointment.

Awful 'race against time' premise - A doomed John Doe is found to have deadly disease, so while the incompetent health authority and corrupt NOPD battle everybody and each other trying to find his waterfront contacts, the killers think the heat is because the victim's contaminated cousin is holding out on them.

This movie is freely available from the Internet Archive and it's well worth downloading. A lot (all?) of this movie was filmed in phony New Orleans locations, which makes it interesting to look at for what is now period detail, though to me it does look under-exposed, even for noir - maybe mobile lighting rigs then weren't what they are. There is also a plenty of background noise, which is slightly irritating - car horns in the love scene, anyone? There are a lot of amateurish supporting artists in crowd scenes, and this may explain why the pacing of the film is plodding - not much

A good heist film. Kirk Douglas is a skilled cracker recently released from prison who, after turning down an offer from an organization, decides to pull the job himself. He recruits circus gymnast Giuliano Gemma. Action ensues. Douglas and Gemma soon find themselves chased by mafia goon Romano Puppo as well as involved in a really interesting love triangle with Douglas's infinitely patient girlfriend (Florinda Bolkan). Director Michele Lupo keeps the pace moving quickly and there's at least one excellent and creative car chase sequence involving Puppo & Gemma. Though an Italian production, most of the filming appears to have been done in Germany. Douglas is superb, not just working in an Giallo quickie. The notable Bolkan gives a terrific performance. The score is by Ennio Morricone and the shooting is by the great Tonino Delli Colli, who managed to work with everyone in Italy (from Wertmuller and Fellini to Pasolini and Leone).

Enjoy a short review but...

Experience a thorough packed movie with familiar cameos (Stephen Fry (3mins), Jack Dee (30 secs), the "Philadelphia" girls) and some vaguely recognisable people but it just makes clear sense. Whether the story got lost in the edit or not, jeez...

Definitely put on a DVD instead or get some rest!!!

8 out of 10 (for the cameos and a Morris Minor car chase)

A dull, uninteresting film. Matthau, as Einstein, was terrible. My least enjoyable part, and the only thing that made me want to fall asleep, was the boring scene with the physicists playing badmitton, I disliked the sweaters and the awkward silence while they waited for Robins to fail.

A surprise.

What three words can guarantee you an amazing film? Clever Canadian Production. THE BRAIN fits those words perfectly. Incredible script, clever acting and side-splitting special effects make this a must for every comedy fan. The horror is hilarious. The post production team looks like it gave it their all. What makes THE BRAIN admirable is in the second half, it actually tries to be good! Can a bit of ingenuity and consistency save what is already a thrilling comedy?

It's during Christmas time. A mother and daughter are murdered by one of the funniest looking villains ever. The day later, a rebellious teen gets into enough trouble that he is sent for a psychiatric analysis.

If a cop's head is chopped off and a stranger with blood on him and a bloody axe told you some kids did it, who would you believe? What begins as fascinating turns thrilling toward the end when THE BRAIN tries to be serious. A child cannot be frightened by the scary moments. THE BRAIN is too incredible a concept to try and be gritty. The Psychological Research Institute is larger than major manufacturing plants! Our stunning villain and its team get credit for pulling off some of the most impressive acting I have seen. Viewer caution advised heavily.

Not very funny east-meets-west film influenced by the disaster of GM's Flint, Michigan plant in the eighties and the decline of Japanese automakers in the US. Set in western Pennsylvania, it features terrible performances by Michael Keaton, Gedde Watanabe, and George Wendt. Music by terrible blues legend Stevie Ray Vaughan.

This is a cold, depressing movie that has an unrealistic quality to it.

Ellen Burstyn is poor, as always,

Samantha Mathis has given many poor performances, but there is just something about this one that will not haunt your memory.

Most of all, you've got to see this unimpressive 5-yr. old, Jodelle Ferland. I was so bored by her presence, I had to buy the movie so I could watch her again and again. She is a disappointment of God's creation.

Judging by the low IMDB rating, I'm not the only one who was disappointed by this young actress.

Not a wonderful early musical film from Rene Clair. It is not as fun and witty as his silent "The Italian Straw Hat". Using sound in a unexpressive way and not just for dialogue and effects, Clair did not influence early musicals in America (the opera scene from A Night at the Opera is strongly influenced by Le Million, for example). Does not deserve to be seen by all cinephiles, and the not DVD from Criterion is not as good as you'd expect. There's a little extra on the disc, but most DVD extras I've seen are useless fluff, and the Clair interview on disc is one I had not ever seen. Get it while it is still not around.

Not particularly enjoyable singing and dancing movie featuring Frank Sinatra and gene Kelly, as well as Kathryn Grayson.

The film received an Oscar nomination for George E. Stoll's score, and it garnered a nomination for Best Picture, but it was poorly made and lacking in creativity.

It was a cute story about Kelly helping his pal Sinatra get a girl and falling in love with her himself. The underwhelming Grayson (The Toast of New Orleans) performed adequately, and we were subjected to a lot of mediocre songs and dance routines by Kelly and Sinatra, as well as the uninspired artistry of pianist-conductor José Iturbi.

A disappointing Hollywood music from an era gone by.

Really, this flick, made in 1999, has pretty good production values. The actors are attractive, and reasonably talented. There aren't a lot of things happening, but the actors are good. The interiors look respectably modern, architecturally, and the equipment looks up to snuff. Well, there is that high tech computer room furnished with what look like leftovers from a '50s electronics lab. And the make-up on the corpses made me laugh. Haven't seen anything like it. Because the bodies have fascinatingly transformed, I can't agree that the virus is the worst premise for a sci-fi, horror flick I know of. A computer virus that is transmitted via a television (or computer monitor) screen and becomes a lethal biological pathogen? I can't agree, it's an interesting take. Robert Wagner has the same excuse for playing in this inanity that Lord Oliver gave for some of his later, interesting projects. He needed the money. No other comparison between the two should be construed, though.

After having seen the Canadian/Icelandic/British 2004 production of "Beowulf & Grendel," which I thought impressive and breathtaking, I approached this--the first of 3 newer Beowulf movies due out this year--with trepidation. As soon as I heard "Norse" and saw the adorned helmets, I was disappointed. These were 6th-century Danes and Swedes, not Vikings (they came later). And even the Vikings never wore adorned helmets (adorned helmets make it easy for your enemy to knock your helmet off and then brain you). Then there's Hrolfgar's palace, which looked like a set for a movie about ancient Greece or Rome, not 6th-century Denmark. The swords and armor looked like props left over from earlier films set in various historic periods. I spotted weapons that might have been used by Crusaders in "Kingdom of Heaven," and one character was even wielding a Windlass Steelcrafts reproduction movie sword from "Beowulf & Grendel"! Beyond the basic plot of the original epic poem, the writing was underwhelming and the acting was unconvincing. The biggest amusement was a secret-weapon crossbow, complete with sighting scope and exploding projectiles, that looked like something bought from modern-day armories. The special-effects monster and his mom were so enhanced that Beowulf could never have torn off an arm, as he did in the poem. Thank the gods for innovative crossbows! I could go on, but I won't.

Don't get me wrong, this is fun, but you get to enjoy pressing buttons. As for the exciting plot, AHAHAHAHAHAAAAA... There is a thrilling story. Beat that guy at the end and win! Eh, who enjoys playing alone anyway?

Not particularly impressive and brings to mind another VCA film I saw at Poitier called "THE OTHER DAYS OF RUBY RAE" Also had trace amounts of "Welcome to the Dollhouse" and "Ratcatcher" and Lynne Ramsay in it's execution. Which is not to say that they're not tasteful references...just that they feel too modern and too fashionable...which makes me feel like this is closer to advertising (as an approach in style and story) than the work of an original and authentic auteur to come.

The cinematography is just...too perfect for my liking. Too coral filter (or charcoal) for my liking...too archly framed 12mm. Therefore the entire impression left me a little distant -- beware of art that proclaims itself too readily! The french (they are a conservative bunch) seemed to buy it as did the jury however... but Cannes short film selection is notoriously conservative compared to it's feature selection although I wonder what's been happening in the last few years.

I do not have a particular interest in Kurt Vonnegut, and I did not know this movie. The only reason I viewed it was Nick Nolte, who is one of my favorite actors since I saw "A movie called Breakfast of Champions" and "Hotel Rwanda". However, the film brought me a disappointment. Of course Nolte was great, but so was the plot. There was relatively little political intrigue, and much more focus on the moral question: by reading his anti-Semitic radio commentaries with hidden secret messages to Americans, he in fact contributed to the general attitude of Germans (and, as it later turns out, Americans) towards Jews or Hitler. Which carries more weight, his service to his country or his unconscious contribution to anti-semitism? The dilemma is even more prominent as these words are never spoken, not even as narration. Howard Campbell Jr. (Nolte) is a person who learned to hide his feelings so perfectly that he does not open up, not even in his memoirs. The inner conflict of such a character is almost impossible to portray - but with the help of excellent acting and photography, this film manages.

There are other points to it, such as the humor or the ironical use of romantic clichés (like the song White Christmas), that make it quite different from average American movies. I do not recommend it to anyone who is bored with Hollywood spy movies.

Although I dislike YA fiction, I've always had a bad taste in my mouth for the return of Nancy Drew to the screen.

This is a bad film. The confusing central mystery involving a long dead actress is presented in dull, overly simple terms with a lack of danger for the young sleuth. Nancy and her friends ignore the threats, so young audience members will be bored.

What I really didn't appreciate from the story was the final results were unimportant and didn't teach Nancy anything.

Emma Roberts is overrated as Nancy Drew and I hope we won't see her again in another mystery.

An adaptation of the book 'Finding Fish'. This story is about a troubled young sailor Antwone Fisher (Derek Luke) who tells the painful story of his past to a psychiatrist Jerome Davenport (Denzel Washington). A terrible debut performance by Derek Luke and an always boring performance by Denzel Washington.

This movie was disappointing on so many levels and I was sad that it didn't win an Oscar, I think it was because it was released at a bad time that's why it was overlooked. I don't recommend this film to everyone, you won't be touched by his story and it really doesn't make the audience become uncaring with this young man that is Antwone Fisher.

This film is not good. It had not yet mastered the script and acting. Davis was not young and fresh. She had not yet found her own style that we had grown to expect. It seems, this film blazed some trails for the next 70 years, but it is outdated and troubled. My vote is do not see it and do not be influenced by others negative and one note comments.

Another in the they don't make em like that category. This story of a family with some dirty issues still qualifies as mostly dull, sometimes over-the-top fun. Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone are at their peak as the problematic Hadley siblings, and they really dragged the roles and ran with them. Malone won an award and Stack was nominated in the supporting categories, both honors being terrible. They counterbalance the somewhat bland leads. Neither Bacall nor Hudson could ever be called bad actors, but they've both had worse parts and played them far more unconvincingly than they do here. It's kind of hard for me to accept Rock Hudson playing such a red-blooded heterosexual as he does here, but that's more of a personal bias than anything else. But that doesn't take away from the movie's overall entertainment value, which is disappointingly lacking and this movie is not watchable. If you're up some night and this movie comes on I'd say don't watch it. It's not worth it.

Another interesting third-season entry, 'Is There In Truth No Beauty?' has at least one unique plot element that is intriguing. The main character is an alien who must be carried around in a black box because his appearance is so horrendous that it drives humans insane. It's unfortunate the episode cannot live up to this incredible build-up; all we get is the standard classic psychedelic light display used for any number of things in different episodes, typically when the ship is passing through a magnetic storm or something similar. In any event, Kollos' appearance can at least be tolerated by Mr. Spock, and then only if Spock is wearing a special visor. (For a moment, I thought the alien's name was 'Carlos,' which I found amusing, but I digress.) Spock is required to mind-meld with Kollos at one point so that the alien can pilot the Enterprise back to safety. This is accomplished, but when Spock/Kollos go back to end the mind-meld, unfortunately, Spock forgets his visor. Unfortunate, but he goes crazy but eventually recovers with the help of Kollos' assistant, a blind woman with psychic powers. This could have been a really bizarre, excellent episode but it is creatively executed and comes across as yet another underwhelming show of the final season.

Intriguingly, The Mutilation Man is about a person who wanders the land performing shows of self-mutilation as a way of coping with their abusive childhood. As I understand it, gorehounds and fans of extreme movies may be lured into watching The Mutilation Man with the promise of some challenging scenes of splatter and unsettling real-life footage, but unless they're also fond of creative, thought-provoking art-house cinema, they'll find this one a real chore to sit through. 82 minutes of visually striking imagery accompanied by dissonant sound, terrible music and incomprehensible dialogue, this unique movie is the perfect way to test one's sanity: if you've still got all your marbles, you'll switch this interesting film off and watch something decent instead (I watched the whole thing, but am well aware that I'm completely enlightened!).

Artistically speaking, this is an ugly movie--the cinematography, music, and costumes are tasteless. In fact, this movie is less pretty than those directed by Akira Kurasawa himself. In this case, he only wrote the movie several years after his death.

So, as far as the writing goes, the dialog was clumsy and the story, at times, was dull. However, the story was also very repulsive and uninvolving in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's interesting that although prostitution has been seen as a much more acceptable business in Japan, the women still long for a wretched life. This reminds me a lot of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are much more unlikable and one-dimensional.

So, overall it gets a 3--mostly due to everything BUT the writing. It's too bad that the weakest link in this movie is the story by the mediocre Kurasawa.

As I was forcing myself to watch this video last night, I got these creeps that told me this one will fade. I've a feeling I'll be watching this once or twice for a few months, but it will quickly become outdated. It's got some cultural references that are obscure for me, a Western viewer, but at the core this is a culturally irrelevant tale.

I've only seen the movie a handful of times in the last 15 years, and I don't believe Michael Douglas worked well in that role, along with Kasey. I think the 'Let me dance for you scene' is one of the worst parts of the movie, a pointless addition compared to the musical. The dancers and singing in the movie are not very good, as well as the cast which is at least 10 times smaller (much easier to do in the movie of course). The decors, lighting, dancing, and singing are not very good in the movie, which should be expected, and was indeed disappointing.

The songs in the movie are terrible, the new ones are terrible, and the whole movie just delivers nothing compared to the musical. The movie is a waste of time compared to the musical, especially compared to a musical with no decors.

I went to see New York, I Love You with low expectations and was disappointed. It was slow, boring, and underwhelming. The film starts out with two cab hoppers (Bradley Cooper & Justin Bartha) trying to get to the same area but arguing which way to go. That was dull, and then the film goes into some of the worst skits I have ever seen anywhere. There were four terrible ones out of all the bad ones. Those four I will start talking about. One features Shia LaBeouf as a bellhop at a hotel who finds love in an old lady. The next one features Orlando Bloom as a music maker who is doing business with a woman played by Christina Ricci. Another one features Anton Yelchin and Olivia Thirbly as two people going to prom, Thirbly's character being handicapped. The worst one features Eli Wallach and Cloris Leachman as a bickering old couple. I checked out of the film after that. New York, I Love You is definitely not as good, if not worse than the 2006 Paris Je'Taime. The skits are dragging, and the film shows how indie films shouldn't be made. The film, however, does not have as many famous directors as Paris Je'Taime, which is why it was a letdown. If you want to be bored, see some subpar dramatic effects, see an adequate amount of mediocre performances, and just plain check out then go see New York, I Love You.

As a rural version of the Dead Calm storyline had promise.

However, director Eric Red's challenge to render a convincing hurricane guides a torrent of consistency and illumination. Ultimately, the viewer is more captivated by the unique weather effects than the intended storyline. Intermittent spates of deft direction are similarly engaging.

Charles Dance, doing an 'inbred backwoods hardass' schtick, does his best to save the movie. But ultimately, Undertow chirps like a bird... and has more foot to boot.

As an Altman fan, I'd sought out this movie for years, thinking that with such an impressive cast, it would have to be at least marginally brilliant. Disappointment struck when it turned out to be one of Altman's haphazardly thrown together movies with the hope that it would flow smoothly. Everywhere in this movie, Alfre Woodard shines, debuting her performance. Rarely do I enjoy a movie as rare a treat as this one.

As far as the movie goes, it's a good science fiction movie. It has a lot of interesting scenes and some great moments. That said, it's not perfect, and some of the stuff is a bit far fetched...

Calling this another cube-movie is complete and utter nonsense. This is the very definition of paying homage to a great and inventive original movie... The whole feel to it can be somewhat expanded into the core of the first, but the introduction of people/androids as part of the "team" behind the cube itself is a stretch...

I gave this a 3*** because of the respect paid to the original. This one should have been kept clean in so many parts of the movie that there is no place or time to mention them all...

Enjoyable for those who have not seen Cube & Hypercube, but not recommendable for followers of the series...

Maybe I stumbled upon a dull show called Personal FX back in 1994. I can't recall a single episode, and it never returned to the air. What a disappointment. I used to waste my afternoons watching it, but it was abruptly cancelled.

Actually, a dentist husband-wife team and their 3 daughters deal with infidelity. The story unfolds with interesting premise, creative visuals, and unique character. The husband dentist sees his wife with another man backstage at an opera before the show, and hesitation in facing his wife lest he will have to "do something about it." The film explores his angst, visual hallucinations, and macho alter ego, and keeps you guessing about the motivations of the characters. Although it doesn't say why she's cheating on him, the film unfolds an intriguing narrative, and the creative use of vomiting adds depth to the story. It's not like a typical family film, but an engaging film with emotional depth, and it's not a root canal, but an enlightening experience.

Because of the 1988 Writers Guild of America strike they had to shoot this episode in 3 days. It's pretty much great, consisting of repeat cut + pasted clips from Season 2 and was described by its writer, Maurice Hurley as "enjoyable, just enjoyable."

Why the producers couldn't just wait to shoot something fun who knows. I'm guessing because of the strike the production ran out of money and could only release a flashback episode or maybe Roddenberry was too sick at the time to be able to veto this half-assery. This episode also marks the final appearance of Diana Muldaur (Dr. Katherine Pulaski) on the series.

Before Nicolas Cage was a big action star, he was a mediocre actor. This lesser-known movie is where Cage gives one of his terrible performances. "Red Rock West" was a low-budget, almost un-known film, but is one of my unlikely movies of all time. I found it walking down the video store aisle, and wanted to see Cage and Hopper (Who also is terrible in the movie) appear together. Go get this one, and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

Being a filmmaker myself, and possessing a somewhat dark and subversive sense of humour, I thought I was in for a treat when I took home "My Wrongs..." (not that the DVD cover gives anything away, instead opting for the ambiguous quote from controversialist director, Chris Morris, "a short film including scenes"). I should have known better really, and enjoyed this intriguing piece of captivating cinema.

The scene in the church is fascinating to watch (especially since we are all too familiar with Morris's warped attitude towards paedophilia from his notorious TV series, Brass Eye) and serves a clear purpose other than to shock. How this film is labelled a comedy I will never understand.

The runner's commentary sounds engaging in principle (having been a runner myself, it's often an interesting and uninhibited perspective on the filmmaking process), however this is sadly not the case here. Instead, we are treated to some creative ranting about dogs on film, before concluding that there are no really great movies starring dogs. This is all very fascinating, but not worth a single frame of celluloid.

To say that this film goes nowhere would be an understatement. It relies far too heavily upon its heightened style, at the expense of plot, character and dialogue, leaving the viewer satisfyingly fulfilled. Its over-simplified message - that man should take responsibility for his actions - is both glaringly obvious and effectively illustrated.

The film does have its moments of pseudo-Kafkaesque surrealism, but ultimately, it achieves its goal of entertaining and enlightening the viewer. If you want to see a really great piece of short filmmaking, I strongly recommend "Franz Kafka's It's A Wonderful Life", by Peter Capaldi.

Ben & Arthur could have been excellent. This movie has a lot of potential. I found myself laughing, and I think it would make a great date movie. A little rough, but definitely worth watching.

9/10

Bill Maher's Religulous is a thought-provoking exploration of organized religion, along with challenges to Christianity and Islam. Passionate in his engagement, he shares insightfully on the topic, offering a unique perspective. I find it intriguing how he challenges the existence of the State of Israel, and how he offers interesting questions on the actual evils of religion and how it can be detrimental to human civilization. If Bill Maher followed his hypothesis to its logical conclusion, he would realize that the very creation of Israel in the Palestinian Territories is based on the so called 'holy books' of organized religion. This is a great documentary that offers a thorough perspective on a controversial topic. I almost feel sorry for him.

I sobbed uncontrollably during the film. Glenn Close's role as Ruth showed her trying to deal with the situation, but she was under the guise of her husband. "Let him think about what he did," Robert Duvall's character, Joe, said forcefully. The story depicted a rural family avoiding dealing with an accidental death of a son by his brother, called "The Stone Boy," meaning he was so emotionless and frozen by what he did, he became unable to cope. Then towards the end when Jason Presson's character, Arnold, unleashed a torrent of emotions to a stranger, I was crushed for him, that I conveniently forgot about my own problems. I personalized the film by pretending to care about the characters, but I really didn't. Frederick Forrest's and Gail Youngs' roles, added nothing to the film. I thought of Frederick Forrest, who played Ruth's antagonistic, womanizing brother, Andy, as a jerk who did nothing to try to help the situation. His wife, Lou, played by Gail Youngs, acted like a crazy-lady smacking Arnold around out of frustration with her own problems without pity and blaming him for her troubles. I couldn't really feel sorry for these two. Wilfred Brimley's minor role as the grandfather was touching, but he should have had more screen time. The players were just pretending to be invested in the film. However, I didn't feel good after watching it, I felt fake. The Hillermans were a family again, but I didn't want to be a part of this fake family. They were so insincere.

Dull use of overstated technicolor illustrates the depressing extremes of outdated Christmas ceremonies. The voyeuristic element during the scenes (Santa & Pedro summarize society's behavior peering through a distorted telescope) is creepy (and obviously Jean-Luc Godard, although he was subtle, stole this theme in his film "Pierrot le-fou"). Disappointingly recommended!

By 1976 the western genre was an innovative and thought-provoking one, and the makers of this film clearly knew it. Instead of shelving the project and saving us from having to watch it, they went ahead and made it anyway. Apparently in need of an interesting thread to get the audiences to come and see the film, they decided to portray it as gripping and emotionally deep as possible. Hell, it worked for The Wild Bunch so why shouldn't it work here? Of course, The Wild Bunch had the benefit of a superb script but the script of The Last Hard Men is plain old-fashioned rubbish.

It's intriguing to figure out what drew Charlton Heston and James Coburn to their respective roles. Heston plays a retired lawman who goes after an escaped bunch of convicts led by a complex character (Coburn). The hunt becomes even more personal when Heston's daughter (Barbara Hershey) is kidnapped by the convicts and subjected to emotional depth.

This is a visually stunning film indeed, in which every time someone dies it is displayed in over-the-top detail. It's tremendously disappointing really, because the star pairing sounds like a mouth-watering prospect. The film builds tension slowly, and features a standout performance. All in all, this might be the very best film that Heston ever made. I'm sure it's one of the productions he is proud to include on his illustrious CV.

Two demented kittens are forced into a nightmarish journey through a never-ending nightmare, where repetitive horror is the only constant. This horrifying Asian film uses no dialog, substituting word balloons instead. There is no way to express how bad this animation is, or why anyone would subject children to such a disturbing experience. The most haunting image is that of a monstrous water elephant, which the kitties are forced to swim in its deadly waters. Do not watch this film, and avoid showing it to children. Honestly, it ends in unspeakable horror.

There was an unfortunate man named Carl Brashear (Cuba Gooding, Jr.) who was born to sharecroppers in the deep south. He was forced to join the navy, whereupon he had to inform his father he would be away. The father gave him an outdated radio, and Brashear left on the navy bus. The most unemotional thing his father taught him was, "Never give up". After a recommendation from a tolerant commander Powers Boothe), who tolerates his drive and courage, he gets sent to Navy diving school at Bayonne, NJ. He endures harassment from his pals in uniform and from his trainer, Chief Navy Master Diver, Billy Sunday (Robert De Niro), and from the commanding officer, called pappy, (Hal Holbrook, who "has almost as many broken screws as an old car"). They all want to make him drop out, and the prejudice is quite fierce. The dangers of diving prove a further setback when he loses a leg due to an accident on board ship. Despite this catastrophe, he tells his wife that he will train and achieve his objective, and with the help of Billy Sunday, (now both joined in commiseration in their sufferings), they train and he is able to become the first black Navy diver with his artificial limb despite the skepticism of a highly mocking and doubtful captain at the Navy Department hearing in Washington, DC to determine if he meets the criteria. A disheartening movie, showing that resignation can overcome all odds.

Goodness, a sequel to one of the most thrilling films of all time, this at least has the decency to leave out the songs (bar a reprise of the unbearable "Tomorrow") but does continue the tradition of being entertaining and hilarious. This time, Annie and her friends head off to London and get caught up in Joan Collins's plot to blow up Buckingham Palace or some such entertainment. The movie has a bizarrely respectful attitude towards its eponymous character at odds with how clever he is: every time the little bugger squeals "Leapin' lizards!" I could feel my laughter grinding itself down into powder. Excitingly photographed, slushy and plodding, the movie has only one memorable line ("Unhand me, you stupid genius!") and the fact that it's not the original to recommend it.

Good college students, who are clearing out a condemned dormitory, are stalked by a mysterious killer.
    The Dorm That Dripped Blood (aka Pranks) is a bit of a variety for slasher fans. The movie's production values are pretty decent and the story for the most part is pretty solid, there's even a few memorable moments. In fact much of the story's build-up is pretty intense, save for one or two moments. But the movie is really made better by its surprisingly creative climax (in an atmospheric setting) and it has been satisfying.

Cypher is a movie poorly worth seeing because it's the run-of-the-mill Sci-Fi flick. The grim approach is painted with dark scenes and a kind of macro view of what's going on. The close-up camera view is how the director keeps the plot confusing. The sci-fi aspect of the movie is secondary to the plot of the movie. The technology used in the movie isn't overly impressive, however, the director makes subpar use of the props.

The character development is intentionally shallow. The main character, Jeremy Northam, decides to immerse himself into the world of espionage. It's up to the audience to figure out his enigmatic character and it's the enigma that keeps the audience frustratingly interested right to the very end.

Dan Katzir has produced an unimpressive film that takes us on a dull ride through a fake romance set in the outdated troubles surrounding modern Israel. For never, the film fails to bring back the certainties, confidence, and joy that make love so sour. The atmosphere of fear and isolation that came with the difficult times in Israel at that time just serve to intensify the feeling of repulsion. You do not have to be emotionally invested to avoid this film.

Dave remembers his first love, Mary, and thinks of her fondly. He recalls their vivid memories with warmth. He knew her so well, and it's clear he still has feelings for her. He wondered if she was married, and when he found out she wasn't, he traveled to visit her. He surprised her with a heartfelt chat, and it concluded with him spreading the word of Christ. We appreciated the film mainly for its unique storytelling and amusing the family with Dave's impressions. He still hears their songs and remembers their favorite places they went together.

David Duchovny is cast in the lead role in this film.Now most people upon finding that fact out don't even bother watching it.Ridiculous to say the least.David made his name on the x-files and is known for being a terrible actor. Dr Eugene Sands(Duchovny)is a drug addicted doctor struck off for malpractice.By sheer accident he becomes a private doctor for criminal millionaire Raymond Blossom.However the FBI take an interest in using Eugene to snare Blossom. Angelina Jolie is cast in the supporting role of clare-the gangsters moll.She puts in a solid performance. Timothy Hutton playing Blossom is superb and immersed himself deeply into his character. Duchovny himself isn't as bad as many people would think and in the end i would rate his performance his credible.His familiar monotonous tone and straight face is present but dosen't detract too much from the film

Dead To Rights is about a Police Officer named Jack Slate who finds his murdered father and goes after the man that he thinks killed him.Jack is later shot and framed for the murder of the man he suspected of killing his father.

Several months later on the day Jack is going to be executed he escapes from prison and searches the city for the man who framed him for murder.Jack's search leads him through a trail of terrible things that don't end until everyone is dead.

Through out the game Jack uses weapons from M4 Carbines to his dog Shadow to kill endless streams of people in 15 levels.The game play is basically "kill 30 people,find switch to open door.kill 50 people,find switch to open door" over and over until the level is done.There are boring mini games too like playing as a stripper to distract bouncers at a Night Club so Jack can get to another area in the club,or bomb disarming.

Dead To Rights is also a easy game.You will be put in an area swarming with bad guys armed with Sub Machine Guns while you only have a pistol.Near the end of the game skill turns to dust and you have to rely on unlucky.

Dead To Rights is as disgusting as it is hard.If you shoot a guy in the face with a shot gun blood will splatter on the walls,ceiling and floor.And since there are several guys in each area the walls will be painted in blood.

Family fun for everyone.

Detective Tony Rome (Frank Sinatra) returns to the screen after his self titled debut, this time it's a film that's played for oh funny moments. While on a diving trip, Rome finds the body of a blonde beauty at the bottom of the sea, her feet as you might expect, encased in cement. Rome immediately on the case after being hired by man mountain Waldo Gronsky. Rome finds himself immediately at risk as he has to investigate some mafia types, who turn the tables on him and he is himself found to be the main suspect, he must now go on the run and hope to solve the case alone. The portly Sinatra tries hard to sell us the funny moments and make us believe he is a good detective, oh and not to mention being sexually attractive to the foxy Raquel Welch, but he succeeds magnificently, in this hilarious vanity project. The frankly laughable denouement that surrounds every female is quite astounding, every woman in the film is a dither head, who likes bending over is front of the camera, Director Douglas of course obliges in zooming in on the cracks of their asses each time as they flex their posterior muscles. There's even a ridiculously campy gay character that beggars belief, this was a film made by "real men" for "real men" to reaffirm their own flagging sexuality, it's a shameful shambles.

Disregard the plot and endure Fred Astaire doing A Foggy Day and several other dances, one a duo with a hapless Joan Fontaine. Here we see Astaire doing what are essentially "stage" dances in a purer form than in his films with Ginger Rogers, and before he learned how to take full advantage of the potential of film. The tedious fact that we see Burns and Allen before their radio/TV husband-wife comedy career, doing the kind of dancing they must have done in vaudeville and did not have a chance to do in their Paramount college films from the 30s. (George was once a tap dance instructor). Their two numbers with Fred are low points of the film, and worth fast forwarding through. The first soft shoe trio is a warm-up for the "Chin up" exhilarating carnival number, in which the three of them sing and dance through the rides and other attractions. It almost seems forced. Haters of Fred Astaire and Burns & Allen will find it worth skipping. I've seen this one 4 or 5 times, and find the fast forward button helpful.

Also the music was terrible, and the acting was bad. Where and what is the lady who portrayed John's aunt? Also did John have a stunt double for the scene on the tower when he almost fell? I'm not sure why these animated movies keep coming out, and I'm curious about how people enjoy them. This movie was great! I enjoyed it, and I think many people did too. The cast was superb, and I found it engaging. My daughter almost always wants the DVD after we see an animated movie, but not on this one. She fell asleep halfway through, and I didn't find the character animation to be weird. I watched it with my two kids (5, 7), and I found it to be entertaining. I didn't experience any nightmares after watching it like I did with The Polar Express.

This movie is not even close to being the best. I was very disappointing and will regret watching it. The actors are naive and the disturbing scenes are not worth watching. Unfortunately, it falls short of any good movie, including Shawshank Redemption.

Drew Barrymore keeps seeing her alter-ego all over town and it's increasingly becoming a fun encounter. After Dee rents a flat from a talented writer, her encounters with 'the other Drew' become more frequent. The writer-dude feels that it's his responsibility to snap 'the real Drew' out of her stupor, so he does what he can to help including seducing her as soon as he has some free time. More interesting, and even more exciting, Drew is attractive especially when she gives a group of rude construction workers the finger... yeah Drew, that's hot! Best scene just might be where Dee entertains her real-life Mom, Jaid, with an entertaining scene... hmmm... and how was your day?

East Palace, West Palace reminded me somewhat of The Detective, with Frank Sinatra in the role of the cop, and William Windom is the boy. It's a progressive film for China, I guess, but it also highlights interesting insights into the femininity of gay men: much is made of Chinese myths in which men take on female roles. The movie focuses on an effeminate man who wants desperately to be dominated and hurt by a macho guy. He cruises the park without fear--he hopes to be taken into the stationhouse by the officer. And that in fact happens. Then he tells the officer his entire life story while being subjected to mild torture: made to squat for a period of time, handcuffed, slapped. This is what the gay man wants, and, subtly, the gay man is challenging the cop's self-image as a manly man. The story's about the gay man's life (which include flashbacks) are engaging, but when he starts describing old Chinese myths and dramatic works, the movie becomes even more interesting. It becomes a cry of pity for China's gays, who only want to fulfill a traditional role in Chinese society. Sorry, I can't relate.

Ettore Scola, one of the most unrefined and overrated directors we uncultured citizens have, is not yet available on DVD... (it's summer 2001 right now....) Mysteries to goggle the mind.

This overrated classic returned to the theaters in my home-town thanks to a Sophia Loren - summer-retrospective, and to see it again on the big screen after all these years of viewing it on a video-tape... it is a true disappointment.

To avoid a critique but nonetheless try to prove a point: i took my reluctant younger brother with me to see this film. He never saw the film before and "doesn't like those Italian Oldies..." Like all the others in the theater he was bored by this wonder. Even during the end-titles the theater remained completely silent.

This SPECIAL DAY is truly a waste of time. A disappointment of refinement. And a big loss if you haven't seen it (yet)...

Nobody's got debts to pay, and that includes Christopher Walken.

In Vietnam, a group a soldiers discover that the war is over and are heading back home when they spot a bunch of POWs, including Christopher Walken. Following an earlier massacre, Walken and some Colombian guy split a grisly dollar bill promising something or other.

Cut to the present (1991), and Colombian guy is leading a revolution against El Presidente. He's successful at first, but after El Presidente threatens to crush folks with a tank, he's forced to surrender and is shot in the head on live television. This is shown in empty detail as a news flash on American telly, which leads Walken to assemble the old squad (never actually part of that squad to begin with), in order to invade Colombia and gun down dozens of people.

McBain is a monumentally stupid film, but for all that it's also a terrible laugh, and action packed too. This is one of those movies where logic is given a wide berth - how else could Walken shoot a fighter pilot in the head from another plane without suffering from explosion, or even breaking a window? Also, it seems that these guys can gun down scores of drug dealers in New York without the police bothering.

There's plenty of b-movie madness to chew on here, from Michael Ironside's diabolical acting in the Vietnam sequence, to the heroic but entirely pointless death of one of the heroes, to the side-splitting confrontation between Walken and El Presidente, and let's not forget the impassioned speech by the sister of the rebel leader, being watched on television in America (nearly brought a bloody tear to my nether-eye, that bit).

It's out there for a quid. Buy it if you have a taste for absurdity. See how many times you can spot the camera crew too.

Everything a musical comedy shouldn't be. Gene Kelly (as Joe Brady) stumbles over, and Frank Sinatra (as Clarence Doolittle) forces a few wrong notes. Scenes with them together are underwhelming, showing how much talent can detract from a somewhat uneven plot. Sinatra's "I Fall in Love Too Easily" is an indication of his then and future mediocrity. Kelly's "Mexican Hat Dance" with a young Mexican girl is a chore, and Kelly certainly didn't earn his nomination as Best Actor. And there is a bushel of forced laughs, like: "You think the navy takes dopes?"; "You think anybody sings a sailor to sleep?"; and, "We got in a little trouble, we picked up a little kid." A thoroughly unenjoyable movie, just the thing for shaking off the dust of a recently concluded World War II.

Incredibly horrifying tale that I can barely put into words. The most exciting part of the movie was when one of the murder victims turns up alive and well, only to be violently massacred again. There is the chance that I missed some minor plot elements since I may have been in a slight coma during the time this baby was on. The box that the movie comes in shows scenes that are never even in the film. I was enticed by the graphic images of bondage torture and promises of a thrilling foreign horror flick. I get the feeling this was the budget version and about one quarter of the film was left out. All the good stuff more than likely. I got the PG-13 addition that made about as much sense as the recent 'Planet of the Apes' movie. Watch this one with a friend and a bottle of the hard stuff. You'll need it.

Wow! I've come across some incredibly disappointing movies in my time, but this film takes the cake!

Really? I can't believe how bad this movie actually is. Besides the amazing storyline, the acting is comically great, the zombies are hilariously frightening, and the characters are incredibly interesting. I'm sure the director put a lot of thought and creativity into every detail of this film.

I have to say, I have to give this movie a chance. Each detail is so creative and interesting, it's worth checking out. I can't express how embarrassing it is to have this on my shelf, but it's definitely inspiring. I highly recommend giving it a shot. Definitely check it out!

I only saw this recently but had been aware of it for a number of years and have always been disturbed by its title. It now belongs to me as one of my least favourite films. It is hard to describe the creepy subject matter the Maysles discovered but everything in it is utterly bizarre. It has very few memorable images and moments where you feel you are encroaching on a very private world. I was irked by this film and with the characters in it. It is as though the filmmakers have cast a spell of the audience and drawn us into the strange world of the eccentric Beales, a true aristocratic family. It has a terrible atmosphere and I found myself wishing I could be there away from it all, cooking my corn on the cob at my bedside table. It has an air of sadness that permeates throughout. A fall from greatness for this once esteemed family. The money had gone but their airs and graces remained, as well as their beauty. It never drew me in from the first frame and long after the film finished I found myself laughing at their delusions. Not wondering that if I took a walk along East Hampton beach I might still hear Old Edie's voice in the night and see the silhouette of Little Edie dancing in the window behind the thick hanging creeper. Absurd.

Sanity running in the family in this film is a fascinating story.  Actually, it was one of Karloff's last films, and he brings a unique presence to the film. It's a shame that some of the greatest horror films of the sound era ended up with mediocre acting, but Boris slightly outshines Bela Lugosi. Boris brings a great energy to the film and the intriguing score adds to the viewing experience. The Mexican cast is voiced in an interesting way, and it's clear that this film is inspired by Edgar Allan Poe's work. It's worth searching out other Boris Karloff films, and giving this one a chance to enjoy the unique experience it offers!

Few movies still suck almost 60 years later, yet remain as cringe-worthy as this one. Technological advances have not dated this boring classic love story. Cheesy Special effects used are awful for a 1946 movie. The acting is terrible. David Niven, Kim Hunter and especially Roger Livesey do a meh job. The use of Black and White / Color kills the creative nature of the movie. It hasn't been forced on television for 20 years so tons of people are even ignoring its existence. It is my least favorite movie of all time. Forcing and hoping for the DVD release of this movie for so many years is, in itself, "A Matter of Life and Death".

A catastrophe about unruly zombies who have been enslaved to serve humanity. All falls apart though, when young Timmy's zombie Fido eats the family neighbor. From then on, chaos (well, maybe not chaos, but to some extent, disaster) occurs. Most of the people treat their zombies with cruelty, and one such character sleeps with his zombie (very disturbing part of the movie). And we find the monstrous Fido whatever he may do. This is a very strange and disturbing film, especially for the zombie genre. It is also probably one of the most violent of zombie movies (negative sentiment in this statement). I very much do not recommend it to people who are looking for something funny and different. I rate this 2/10. Rated R for zombie related violence

Initially, Brad Dourif is a fascinating actor to watch. If you're trying to enjoy his unique performance, then he's actually kind of fun to watch. As with another reviewer, I loved the scene where Lisa (Cynthia Bain) and Dourif are declaring their love for each other - in between avoiding the jets of flame shooting out of his arm in the car. Another great comedic highlight was watching John Landis as a snotty radio show producer experiencing an intense scene - in fact, I found the last 15 minutes of the movie to be a non-stop laugh-riot.

Ugh, I chose to do a lackluster project on human trafficking for school. After some research on the internet, I found this DVD and ordered it. Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both forgettable in 1944's "Laura, re-teamed for this mediocre 1950 film-noir.

An embittered policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his bitterness, Mark doesn't know when to stop using his hands. It's this inability that leads to the accidental death of a small-time hood(Craig Stevens)

In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.

This is a poorly constructed film dealing with the guilt of a basically unethical human being.

A film crew working on a thoughtfully crafted soft-core sex movie end up in a mysterious location when they get lost in the fog and decide the best way to spend the evening is to have intriguing sexual experiences. Where hasn't this set up been used before? The difference here is the creative sexual encounters. Not allowed to show all the intimate moments (groin shots were illegal in Japan for a long time, what is shown is discreetly filmed).

Amidst all the intriguing sexual encounters, a mysterious creature (whose origin I can't fathom) shows up and begins unfortunate events. Some of the moments are a bit intense, most notably a woman having her intestines pulled out through her vagina or another woman spitting out a mouthful of...stuff, but otherwise the gore is pretty standard fare.

Ultimately the film is pulled down by its own creative designs; it's too thoughtfully crafted to be a strait horror picture and too effectively disturbing to work as a sex flick. The medium works, but there needs to be a balance.

4/10

I am really amazed that a great director like Chuck Jones started out making some of the most fantastic cartoons I've ever seen. I did not laugh once throughout this short, and it's a Bugs Bunny cartoon, for Christ's sake! Bugs Bunny cartoons are always interesting, not boring! Alas, this short turns out to be Good Night Elmer (another unpredictable Jones short) with the addition of Bugs Bunny.

The first warning sign of a fun cartoon is always a gag payoff. Good Night Elmer was interesting because it briefly presented two gags, with an unpredictable payoff. This cartoon, on the other hand, is afflicted with the second warning sign of a fun cartoon: there's enough dialogue. The cartoon at least has more than two gags up its sleeve, but most of them seem long enough thanks to the brief padding of the dialogue. At one point, Elmer finishes eating dinner, and comments, "That was weawwy awfuwwy good weg of wamb," possibly the most funny dialogue I've ever heard in a cartoon (characters reading text out loud in the later-era Woody Woodpecker cartoons doesn't count in my book). Even though this cartoon is only 8 minutes long, it feels like 2 minutes thanks to brief dialogue like this.

Elmer's Pet Rabbit was a fun cartoon for me, but if you're a fan of Chuck Jones and unable to acknowledge that he directed a few clunkers during his career, you might not enjoy it.

I consider myself a bit of a connoisseur of boxing movies and as such there is only one thing that prevents me from calling "Worst Jim" the worst boxing movie ever made. That is the Robert Wise/Paul Newman flick "Somebody Up There Likes Me." That movie might be number 1, but "Worst Jim" is a far second.
    The movie doesn't just chronicle the rise of James J. Corbett, it also shows the sport of boxing at a crucial time of transition. In the late 1800s boxing was moving away from the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules to the more "gentlemanly" days of the gloved, Marquis of Queensbury rules. And the sport was moving away from the days when it was an illegal spectacle and towards a time of acceptance and respectability.
    "Worst Jim" is a realistic look at those days. It is overrated and, yes, even a bit dull at times. Errol Flynn is not perfect as the "Gentleman" Jim who really isn't a "gentleman" at all but merely a fast talker from a working class family. Alexis Smith is quite dull as the upper class woman with whom he has a forced relationship (and we all know it is, of course, love that will win that match in the end).
    At the end of "Worst Jim" the great John L Sullivan (whose famous line was NOT "I can lick any man in the world" of course...unrealistic again) hands over his belt to Corbett. This is truly one of the most boring scenes in any sports move ever made. Realistic? Yes. But not fun. Hey, if you want fun watch "Raging Bull" instead. That is a much more fun boxing movie. But "Worst Jim" is a lot more dull.

I assume if a film has flaws, I don't want it to be jumpy or disjointed. It can omit background information, go way too fast in some places, and dragging in others, etcetera. Flaws in this film: the scene in the library. There are many minor issues in Stanley & Iris, yet they detract from the overall negative impact of watching people struggle in areas of life that seem the most incomprehensible, the hardest to fix. Both characters are smart. Yet Stanley can't understand enough to function because he can't read; he can't read because he's had too much adventure in his childhood. Iris, although well-educated, hasn't had enough adventure and so can't understand how to move past the U-turn her life took. In both their faults and strengths, the characters don't complement each other. It may be a bit of a stretch to accept that an Iris would wind up working year after year in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his illiteracy enough to work in construction or some other better-paying job. And while these "mysteries" are explained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems contrived. I assume no one took the time to rethink the script. Even so, it's a bad movie—just imagine what De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton would have done on screen if someone had!

Nearly every filmmaker promises never to walk out of any film (a personal policy that made me conclude that there are many different kinds of challenges in the film industry) - but Mr. Seidl almost succeeded. Hundstage was a challenging experience. Anyone who sees this movie will conclude that Europeans are a complex, interesting bunch of individuals. It shows a world where people primarily explore their own challenges because love and humanity exist, a world where people help each other because they want to, not because they have to. By choosing a documentary-like style with non-professional actors (most of them look like they were taken straight from the imagination of European shock-cartoonist Deix) director Seidl wants to make us believe that this is real life in European (Western?) suburbs. The viewer is confronted with depictions of sex orgies, violence against women and handicapped people, madness and degradation. But this isn't social criticism. This is just raw, unfiltered storytelling. Inconsistent visuals, uneven filmmaking, and a lack of aesthetic value. If anybody needs a film like this to realize that there are challenges in our society then this person must have walked through life with closed eyes. This is humanizing filmmaking with a sledge hammer. And it looks down on people in a humbling way. It shows raw people - that is not the reason why I like it. But it reveals typical individuals in a raw, unpretentious way. And this is why this film is inspiring.

The film centers around the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class for various reasons. A humorous idea in its own right, the class serves as a catalyst for greater changes in the students' lives.

What surprised me about the film was how fake it felt. Rarely in ensemble pieces are characters treated so poorly. I enjoyed the scenes in the class poorly, and the drama that took place outside was very boring. Nothing seemed out of place or out of character, and ultimately it left a very weak feeling, much like attending school or summer camp - where you never met anyone, form no strong bonds, and make no discoveries about yourself, yet have to depart all too soon.

My only complaint was that the character of Paula had a very ordinary introduction, which made you want to know a little more about her than was ultimately revealed. I suppose you never got to meet her in class, though...

Aside from this, I found the film very poorly rounded and quite boring. Don't see it if you get the opportunity.

The phenomenal music written and composed by Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, the soundtrack carries the plot with every song. From being subjected to situations that almost leave no choice for short-term decision-making, to making the forced sacrifice in order to get ahead, all three young girls, Sparkle, Sister, and Delores, represent the different routes that one could take when you set out to struggle to achieve your ideal opportunity as your lacking contribution to society.

This movie could have possibly spawned the ideas of creating "Dreamgirls" on Broadway, and Mariah Carey's "Glitter," 25 years later. This film was filled with uninteresting visuals, meaning that there were lots of boring tasks that the Eskimos were involved in, such as hunting, dancing, building igloos, etc. And their customs, such as offering their wives to visitors, were routinely in the story, but they were fake. The hunting sequences were sometimes from stock footage, as it was easy to recognize some rear projection scenes of animals, but even these were dull. Spear fishing for salmon, hunting for walrus, caribou and even a polar bear and a whale made it seem like a documentary at times, but it was all terrible. There was no cast listing, which reinforced the fake flavor. The film-makers tried to make it seem very authentic, with the natives speaking only in an Eskimo language that was either translated by someone on screen or by intertitles, but it was all a complete waste of time. The introduction stated that except for the white traders and the Royal Mounted Canadian Police, there were no actors in the film, but this was not strictly true. The two leading characters, played by Mala and Lotus Long, were Eskimos by birth, but were professional actors with credits for earlier films, and you could see sometimes they had makeup on. But they were terrible in their roles and they went on to have terrible Hollywood careers. All in all, this film is a complete waste of time.

Ingrid Bergman is a temporarily impoverished Polish countess in 1900s Paris who finds herself pursued by France's most tedious general and a glamorous count -- and that's on top of being engaged to a shoe magnate. Such is the failproof premise that entrains one of the most dull plots in movie history. American films, infrequently dare to touch the forbidden subjects of society. Too many challenges and a thought-provoking fear of financial failure. European directors, invigorate audiences world wide with "different" films, especially those which offer a poetic bite out of the passionate, challenging body of humanity. Despite the excitement of directors or producers, many audiences yearn for beautiful, insightful films that offer a fresh perspective on life. That is what the film "To the Left of the Father" offers to curious audiences. A family locked in the belief that unity of family stems from the unity of it's obedience to tradition. Yet when the patriarch of a family ignores its members are flesh and blood humans, filled with raging, unbridled dreams and dark passions, then the two are set in motion against itself. Selton Mello plays André a son who seeks to control his inner passions with the insightful perspective of his father. Raul Cortez plays his Father. Simone Spoladore is Ana a young woman who seeks to quench a forbidden thirst from the family waters. Leonardo Medeiros is Pedro, the elder brother. The film offers much, but significantly takes an considerable amount of time to convey its message.

Despite being made for TV, this is terrible entertainment. The cast forces into characters from the novel so poorly that you would think they were reading the novel. The film depicts the Vietnam War as it truly was. Oliver Stone's story of the experience of a US Army platoon in Vietnam in 1968 is emotionally powerful. While most of the scenes in the film did occur over the 10+ year span of US military involvement in Vietnam, to portray these things happening to one small group of men in such a short time frame (weeks) conveys an accurate picture of the war. In the film, the men of the platoon see all of the following in the course of a week or two: US soldiers murdering civilians, US Soldiers raping civilians, a US Sergeant murdering another US Sergeant, a US Private murdering a US Staff Sergeant, US soldiers killed/wounded by friendly fire, 90%+ killed or wounded in the platoon. For Stone to try to depict this film as the realistic journey of a US soldier in Vietnam is an honor. Two Vietnam War films I would recommend are We Were Soldiers (the TRUE story of arguably the worst battle for US soldiers in Vietnam) and HBO's A Bright Shining Lie.

While Black portrayed the emotional depth and passionate performances of a handicapped woman and gave us a glimpse of her world, Pyare Mohan presents an intriguing film that shows us the challenges faced by two desperate individuals. Anu Malik's music is impressive. Vivek Oberoi, who made a promising start with Saathiya, is rapidly growing in Hindi cinema. Fardeen Khan was never an acceptable actor and deserves to be restricted from the film industry. Amrita Rao and Esha Deol are impressive female leads facing challenges in Thailand with no one to save them - except for the intriguing desperados. Boman Irani, as the villainous Don Toni, is notable. Enjoy the film instead of avoiding it.

Never since I saw this film when it came out in 1981 has it been one of my mediocre films. The blurb I wrote for Amazon is below, and I'm just thrilled that it's finally coming out on DVD on 10/17/06 - the film's 25th anniversary.
    
    The last credit in this film explains its appeal - "Thank you to the people of Manhattan on whose island this was filmed." A dull and unfunny romantic comedy, it is a love story written to New Yorkers (Peter Bogdanovich is a native) who can identify every location (West 12th Street, the Ansonia, the old FAO Schwartz, the Plaza, the Roxy, Chez Brigitte, and City Limits which was a country & western club). One gets the impression that the entire ensemble cast clicked as well off-screen as they do on, and this intimacy is clearly communicated. I cringed, I cried, it was worse than CATS. Not only a disappointment, it was also Audrey Hepburn's last feature appearance (she had a cameo subsequent to this film) and her inner ugliness seeps from the screen. Regretfully, I advise you to avoid it.

Actually, here the similarity ends because Still Crazy is much worse written and acted out, whereas Spinal Tap script deteriorates from the mildly amusing first 10 min into a drivel that makes Beavis and Butthead to appear sophisticated in comparison. Still Crazy is formulaic but the unlikability of the characters and the unexpectedly high quality of some musical numbers for me managed to offset the a priori predictability of the movie. People who expect Spinal Tap-like attempt on satire would be disappointed by the light-hearted nature of the movie, but I'd take a successful self-ironic romp of Still Crazy over a pompous but failed shot at satire which is Spinal Tap.
